statements.name: PROC LIFEREG
statements.description: The LIFEREG procedure fits parametric models to failure time data that can be uncensored, right censored, left censored, or interval censored. The models for the response variable consist of a linear effect composed of the covariates and a random disturbance term. The distribution of the random disturbance can be taken from a class of distributions that includes the extreme value, normal, logistic, and, by using a log transformation, the exponential, Weibull, lognormal, log-logistic, and three-parameter gamma distributions.

arguments.name: COVOUT
arguments.description: Writes the estimated covariance matrix to the OUTEST= data set if convergence is attained.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set used by PROC LIFEREG. By default, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: GOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies a graphics catalog in which to save graphics output.

arguments.name: INEST=
arguments.description: Specifies an input SAS data set that contains initial estimates for all the parameters in the model.

arguments.name: NAMELEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of effect names in tables and output data sets to be n characters, where n is a value between 20 and 200. The default length is 20 characters.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the output.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sorting order for the levels of the classification variables (specified in the CLASS statement).

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the order of appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the descending frequency count; levels with the most observations come first in the order.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the unformatted value.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Specifies an output SAS data set containing the parameter estimates, the maximized log likelihood, and, if the COVOUT option is specified, the estimated covariance matrix.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies one of two graphics options: NONE or PROBPLOT

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses any graphics specified in other LIFEREG statements, such as the BAYES or PROBPLOT statement.

arguments.name: PROBPLOT
arguments.description: Creates a default probability plot based on information in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: XDATA=
arguments.description: Specifies an input SAS data set that contains values for all the independent variables in the MODEL statement and variables in the CLASS statement for probability plotting.

statements.name: BAYES
statements.description: The BAYES statement requests that the parameters of the model be estimated by Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling techniques. The FMM procedure can estimate by maximum likelihood the parameters of all models supported by the procedure. Bayes estimation, on the other hand, is available for only a subset of these models. In Bayesian analysis, it is essential to examine the convergence of the Markov chains before you proceed with posterior inference. With ODS Graphics turned on, the FMM procedure produces graphs at the end of the procedure output; these graphs enable you to visually examine the convergence of the chain. Inferences cannot be made if the Markov chain has not converged. The output produced for a Bayesian analysis is markedly different from that for a frequentist (maximum likelihood) analysis for the following reasons: o Parameter estimates do not have the same interpretation in the two analyses. Parameters are fixed unknown constants in the frequentist context and random variables in a Bayesian analysis. o The results of a Bayesian analysis are summarized through chain diagnostics and posterior summary statistics and intervals. o The FMM procedure samples the mixing probabilities in Bayesian models directly, rather than mapping them onto a logistic (or other) scale. The FMM procedure applies highly specialized sampling algorithms in Bayesian models. For single-component models without effects, a conjugate sampling algorithm is used where possible. For models in the exponential family that contain effects, the sampling algorithm is based on Gamerman (1997). For the normal and t distributions, a conjugate sampler is the default sampling algorithm for models with and without effects. In multi-component models, the sampling algorithm is based on latent variable sampling through data augmentation (Frühwirth-Schnatter 2006) and the Gamerman or conjugate sampler. Because of this specialization, the options for controlling the prior distributions of the parameters are limited.

arguments.name: COEFFPRIOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the prior distribution for the regression coefficients. The default is COEFFPRIOR=UNIFORM.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Syntax: NORMAL<(options)> Specifies a normal distribution. The normal-options include the following: CONDITIONAL specifies that the normal prior, conditional on the current Markov chain value of the location-scale model precision parameter τ=1/σ², is N(µ,τ⁻¹Z), where µ and Z are the mean and covariance of the normal prior specified by other normal options. INPUT=SAS-data-set specifies a SAS data set containing the mean and covariance information of the normal prior. The data set must have a _TYPE_ variable to represent the type of each observation and a variable for each regression coefficient. RELVAR<=c> Specifies the normal prior N(0, cJ), where J is a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements equal to the variances of the corresponding ML estimator. By default, c=10⁶. VAR<=c> Specifies the normal prior N(0,cI), where I is the identity matrix.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: Specifies a flat prior.

arguments.name: DIAGNOSTICS=
arguments.description: Controls the number of diagnostics produced.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all posterior diagnostics.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses the computation of posterior diagnostics.

arguments.name: (keyword-list)
arguments.description: The following keywords enable you to select subsets of posterior diagnostics; the default is DIAGNOSTICS=(AUTOCORR ESS GEWEKE): AUTOCORR<(LAGS= numeric-list)> Computes for each sampled parameter the autocorrelations of lags specified in the LAGS= list. ESS -- Computes Carlin’s estimate of the effective sample size, the correlation time, and the efficiency of the chain for each parameter. GELMAN <(gelman-options)> computes the Gelman and Rubin convergence diagnostics. You can specify one or more of the following gelman-options: NCHAIN=number | N=number specifies the number of parallel chains used to compute the diagnostic, and must be 2 or larger. The default is NCHAIN=3. ALPHA=value specifies the significance level for the upper bound. The default is ALPHA=0.05, resulting in a 97.5% bound. GEWEKE<(geweke-options)>-- Computes the Geweke spectral density diagnostics, which are essentially a two-sample t test between the first f1 portion and the last f2 portion of the chain. The default is f1=0.1 and f2=0.5. The geweke-options are: FRAC1=value -- Specifies the fraction f1 for the first window. FRAC2=value -- Specifies the fraction f2 for the second window. HEIDELBERGER<(heidel-options)> -- Computes the Heidelberger and Welch diagnostic (which consists of a stationarity test and a half-width test) for each variable. The heidel-options are: SALPHA=value -- Specifies the α level for the stationarity test. By default, SALPHA=0.05. HALPHA=value -- Specifies the α level for the halfwidth test. By default, HALPHA=0.05. EPS=value -- Specifies a positive number ε such that if the halfwidth is less than ε times the sample mean of the retained iterates, the halfwidth test is passed. MCERROR | MCSE --Computes an estimate of the Monte Carlo standard error for each parameter. MAXLAG=n -- specifies the largest lag used in computing the effective sample size and the Monte Carlo standard error. Specifying this option implies the ESS and MCERROR options. The default is MAXLAG=250. RAFTERY<(raftery-options)> -- Computes Raftery and Lewis diagnostics that evaluate accuracy of the estimated quantile of a chain. raftery-options are: QUANTILE= | Q=value -- Specifies the order (a value between 0 and 1) of the quantile of interest. The default is 0.025. ACCURACY= | R=value -- Specifies a small positive number as the margin of error for measuring the accuracy of estimation of the quantile. The default is 0.005. PROBABILITY= | S=value -- Specifies the probability of attaining the accuracy of the estimation of the quantile. The default is 0.95. EPSILON= | EPS=value -- Specifies the tolerance level (a small positive number) for the stationary test. The default is 0.001.

arguments.name: EXPSCALEPRIOR=
arguments.description: Syntax: EXPSCALEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> | IMPROPER ESCALEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> | IMPROPER ESCPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> | IMPROPER Specifies that Gibbs sampling be performed on the exponential distribution scale parameter and the prior distribution for the scale parameter. This prior distribution applies only when the exponential distribution and no covariates are specified.

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Syntax: GAMMA<(options)> A gamma prior G(a,b) with density f(t) is specified by EXPSCALEPRIOR=GAMMA, which can be followed by one of the following gamma-options enclosed in parentheses. The hyperparameters a and b are the shape and inverse-scale parameters of the gamma distribution, respectively. RELSHAPE<=c> specifies independent distribution G(cἂ,c), where ἂ is the MLE of the exponential scale parameter. With this choice of hyperparameters, the mean of the prior distribution is ἂ and the variance is ἂ/c². By default, c=10⁻⁴. SHAPE=a | ISCALE=b when both specified, results in a G(a,b) prior. SHAPE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior. ISCALE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior

arguments.name: IMPROPER
arguments.description: Specifies an improper prior with density f(t) proportional to t⁻¹.

arguments.name: GAMMASHAPEPRIOR=
arguments.description: Syntax: GAMMASHAPEPRIOR=NORMAL<(options)> GAMASHAPEPRIOR=NORMAL<(options)> SHAPE1PRIOR=NORMAL<(options)> Specifies the prior distribution for the gamma distribution shape parameter. If you do not specify any options in a gamma model, the N(0, 10⁶) prior for the shape is used. You can specify MEAN= and VAR= or RELVAR= options, either alone or together, to specify the mean and variance of the normal prior for the gamma shape parameter.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Syntax: NORMAL<(options)> You can specify MEAN= and VAR= or RELVAR= options, either alone or together, to specify the mean and variance of the normal prior for the gamma shape parameter. MEAN=a specifies a normal prior N(a, 10⁶). By default, a=0. RELVAR<=b> specifies the normal prior N(0, 1bJ), where J is the variance of the MLE of the shape parameter. By default, b=10⁶. VAR=c specifies the normal prior N(0, c). By default, c=10⁶.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS data set that contains the initial values of the Markov chains. The INITIAL= data set must contain all the variables of the model. You can specify multiple rows as the initial values of the parallel chains for the Gelman-Rubin statistics, but posterior summaries, diagnostics, and plots are computed only for the first chain. If the data set also contains the variable _SEED_, the value of the _SEED_ variable is used as the seed of the random number generator for the corresponding chain.

arguments.name: METROPOLIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the use of a Metropolis step to generate Gibbs samples for posterior distributions that are not log concave. The default value is METROPOLIS=YES.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies to use a Metropolis step to generate Gibbs samples for posterior distributions that are not log concave.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies not to use a Metropolis step to generate Gibbs samples for posterior distributions that are not log concave.

arguments.name: NBI=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of burn-in iterations before the chains are saved. The default is 2000.

arguments.name: NMC=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of iterations after the burn-in. The default is 10000.

arguments.name: OUTPOST=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the posterior samples. Alternatively, you can create the output data set by specifying an ODS OUTPUT statement as follows:

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Syntax: PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>= plot-request PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>= (plot-request < …plot-request>) Controls the display of diagnostic plots. The global plot options are as follows: FRINGE creates a fringe plot on the X axis of the density plot. GROUPBY=PARAMETER | GROUPBY=TYPE specifies how the plots are grouped when there is more than one type of plot. GROUPBY=TYPE specifies that the plots be grouped by type. GROUPBY=PARAMETER specifies that the plots be grouped by parameter.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Specifies all types of plots. PLOTS=ALL is equivalent to specifying PLOTS=(TRACE AUTOCORR DENSITY).

arguments.name: AUTOCORR
arguments.description: Displays the autocorrelation function plots for the parameters.

arguments.name: DENSITY
arguments.description: Displays the kernel density plots for the parameters.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all diagnostic plots.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: Displays the trace plots for the parameters.

arguments.name: SCALEPRIOR=
arguments.description: Specifies that Gibbs sampling be performed on the location-scale model scale parameter and the prior distribution for the scale parameter.

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Syntax: GAMMA<(options)> A gamma prior G(a,b) with density f(t) is specified by SCALEPRIOR=GAMMA, which can be followed by one of the following gamma-options enclosed in parentheses. The hyperparameters a and b are the shape and inverse-scale parameters of the gamma distribution, respectively. RELSHAPE<=c> specifies independent distribution G(cἂ,c), where ἂ is the MLE of the scale parameter. With this choice of hyperparameters, the mean of the prior distribution is ἂ and the variance is ἂ/c. By default, c=10⁻⁴. SHAPE=a | ISCALE=b when both specified, results in a G(a,b) prior. SHAPE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior. ISCALE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior

arguments.name: IMPROPER
arguments.description: Specifies an improper prior with density f(t) proportional to t⁻¹.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer seed in the range 1 to 2³¹-1 for the random number generator in the simulation. Specifying a seed enables you to reproduce identical Markov chains for the same specification. If the SEED= option is not specified, or if you specify a nonpositive seed, a random seed is derived from the time of day.

arguments.name: STATISTICS=
arguments.description: Syntax: STATISTICS <(global-options)> = ALL | NONE | keyword | (keyword-list) STATS <(global-statoptions)> = ALL | NONE | keyword | (keyword-list) Controls the number of posterior statistics produced. The global-options include the following: ALPHA=numeric-list controls the probabilities of the credible intervals. The ALPHA= values must be between 0 and 1. Each ALPHA= value produces a pair of 100(1–ALPHA)% equal-tail and HPD intervals for each parameters. The default is ALPHA=0.05, which yields the 95% credible intervals for each parameter.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Produces the posterior correlation matrix.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Produces the posterior covariance matrix.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Produces the means, standard deviations, and percentile points for the posterior samples. The default is to produce the 25th, 50th, and 75th percentil epoints, but you can use the global PERCENT= option to request specific percentile points.

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: Produces equal-tail credible intervals and HPD intervals. The default is to produce the 95% equal-tail credible intervals and 95% HPD intervals, but you can use the global ALPHA= option to request intervals of any probabilities.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses printing all summary statistics.

arguments.name: THINNING=
arguments.description: Controls the thinning of the Markov chain. The default is THINNING=1.

arguments.name: WEIBULLSCALEPRIOR=
arguments.description: Syntax: WEIBULLSCALEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> WSCALEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> WSCPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)>

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Syntax: GAMMA<(options)> A gamma prior G(a,b) is specified by WEIBULLSCALEPRIOR=GAMMA, which can be followed by one of the following gamma-options enclosed in parentheses. The hyperparameters a and b are the shape and inverse-scale parameters of the gamma distribution, respectively. RELSHAPE<=c> specifies independent distribution G(cἂ,c), where ἂ is the MLE of the Weibull scale parameter. With this choice of hyperparameters, the mean of the prior distribution is ἂ and the variance is ἂ/c. By default, c=10⁻⁴. SHAPE=a | ISCALE=b when both specified, results in a G(a,b) prior. SHAPE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior. ISCALE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior

arguments.name: WEIBULLSHAPEPRIOR=
arguments.description: Syntax: WEIBULLSHAPEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> WSHAPEPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)> WSHPRIOR=GAMMA<(options)>

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Syntax: GAMMA<(options)> A gamma prior G(a,b) is specified by WEIBULLSHAPEPRIOR=GAMMA, which can be followed by one of the following gamma-options enclosed in parentheses. The hyperparameters a and b are the shape and inverse-scale parameters of the gamma distribution, respectively. RELSHAPE<=c> specifies independent distribution G(cḂ,c), where Ḃ is the MLE of the Weibull shape parameter. With this choice of hyperparameters, the mean of the prior distribution is Ḃ and the variance is Ḃ/c. By default, c=10⁻⁴. SHAPE=a | ISCALE=b when both specified, results in a G(a,b) prior. SHAPE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior. ISCALE=c when specified alone, results in a G(c,c) prior

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement with PROC LIFEREG to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified is used.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used in the model. Typical classification variables are Treatment, Sex, Race, Group, and Replication. If you use the CLASS statement, it must appear before the MODEL statement. Classification variables can be either character or numeric. By default, class levels are determined from the entire set of formatted values of the CLASS variables.

statements.name: EFFECTPLOT
statements.description: The EFFECTPLOT statement produces a display of the fitted model and provides options for changing and enhancing the displays.

arguments.name: BOX=
arguments.description: Displays a box plot of continuous response data at each level of a CLASS effect, with predicted values superimposed and connected by a line. This is an alternative to the INTERACTION plot-type.

arguments.name: CONTOUR=
arguments.description: Displays a contour plot of predicted values against two continuous covariates.

arguments.name: FIT=
arguments.description: Displays a curve of predicted values versus a continuous variable.

arguments.name: INTERACTION=
arguments.description: Displays a curve of predicted values versus a continuous variable grouped by the levels of a CLASS effect.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level, 0 ≥ value ≥ 1, for producing 100(1-value/2)% prediction and confidence limits. By default, value=0.05.

arguments.name: AT
arguments.description: where contopt= MEAN | MIN | MAX | MIDRANGE classopt= ALL | REF varopt= contopts | number-list | classopts | ’class-level’...’class-level’]

arguments.name: ATLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum length (1 < n < 256) of the levels of the AT variables that are displayed in footnotes and headers. By default, up to 256 characters of the CLASS levels are displayed, and the continuous AT levels are displayed with a BEST format that has a width greater than or equal to 5, which distinguishes each level. Caution:If the levels of your AT variables are not unique when the first n characters are displayed, then the levels are combined in the plots but not in the underlying computations. Also, at most n characters for continuous AT variables are displayed.

arguments.name: ATORDER=
arguments.description: Uses the AT values for continuous variables in ascending or descending order as specified. By default, values are used in the order of their first appearance in the AT option.

arguments.name: ASCENDING
arguments.description: Uses the AT values for continuous variables in ascending order

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Uses the AT values for continuous variables in descending order

arguments.name: CLI
arguments.description: Displays normal (Wald) prediction limits. This option is available only for normal distributions with identity links. If your model is from a Bayesian analysis, then sampling-based intervals are computed.

arguments.name: CLM
arguments.description: Displays confidence limits. These are computed as the normal (Wald) confidence limits for the linear predictor, and if the ILINK option is specified, the limits are also back-transformed by the inverse link function. If your model is from a Bayesian analysis, then sampling-based intervals are computed.

arguments.name: CLUSTER
arguments.description: Modifies the BOX and INTERACTION plot-types by displaying the levels of the SLICEBY= effect in a side-by-side fashion. You can specify percent as a percentage of half the distance between X levels. The percent value must be between 0.1 and 1; the default percent depends on the number of X levels, the number of SLICEBY levels, and the number of PLOTBY levels for INTERACTION plot-types. Default clustering can be removed by specifying the NOCLUSTER option.

arguments.name: CONNECT
arguments.description: Modifies the BOX and INTERACTION plot-types by connecting the predicted values with a line. Default connecting lines can be removed by specifying the NOCONNECT option.

arguments.name: EXTEND=
arguments.description: Extends continuous covariate axes by value x ½range in both directions, where range is the range of the X axis.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Displays curves to the range of the data within the appropriate SLICEBY=, PLOTBY=, and AT level.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Replace <value> with an actual value.

arguments.name: GRIDSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the resolution of curves by computing the predicted values at n equally spaced x-values and specifies the resolution of surfaces by computing the predicted values on an nxn grid of points. Default values are n=200 for curves and bands, n=50 for surfaces, and n=2 for lines. If results of a Bayesian or bootstrap analysis are being displayed, then the defaults are n=500000/B, where B is the number of samples, the upper limit is equal to the usual defaults, and the lower limit equal to 20.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Displays the fit on the scale of the inverse link function. In particular, the results are displayed on the probability scale for logistic regression. By default, a procedure displays the fit on either the link or inverse link scale.

arguments.name: INDIVIDUAL
arguments.description: Displays individual probabilities for polytomous response models with cumulative links on the scale of the inverse link function. This option is not available when the LINK option is specified, and confidence limits are not available with this option.

arguments.name: LIMITS
arguments.description: Invokes the CLI and CLM options.

arguments.name: LINK
arguments.description: Displays the fit on the scale of the link function; that is, the linear predictor. Note that probabilities or observed proportions near 0 and 1 are transformed to . By default, a procedure displays the fit on either the link or inverse link scale.

arguments.name: MOFF
arguments.description: Moves the offset for a Poisson regression model to the response side of the equation. If the ILINK option is also in effect, then the rate is displayed on the Y axis, while the LINK option displays the log of the rate on the Y axis. Without this option, the predicted values are computed and displayed only for the observations.

arguments.name: NCOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of columns in a paneled plot. This option is not available with the BOX plot-type. The default choice of NROWS= and NCOLS= is based on the number of PLOTBY= and AT levels. If there is only one plot being displayed in a panel, then NROWS=1 and NCOLS=1 and the plots are produced as if you specified only the UNPACK option. If only two plots are displayed in a panel, then NROWS=1 and NCOLS=2. For all other cases, a 2x2, 2x3, or 3x3 panel is chosen based on how much of the last panel is used, with ties going to the larger panels. For example, if 14 plots are being created, then this requires either four 2x2 panels with 50% of the last panel filled, three 2x3 panels with 33% of the last panel filled, or two 3x3 panels with 55% of the last panel filled; in this case, the 3x3 panels are chosen.

arguments.name: NOCLI
arguments.description: Suppresses the prediction limits.

arguments.name: NOCLM
arguments.description: Suppresses the confidence limits.

arguments.name: NOLIMITS
arguments.description: Invokes the NOCLI and NOCLM options.

arguments.name: NOOBS
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of observations and overrides the specification of the OBS= option.

arguments.name: NROWS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of rows in a paneled plot. This option is not available with the BOX plot-type. See the NCOLS= option for more details.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.description: Displays observations on the effect plots. An input data set is required; hence the OBS option is not available with PROC PLM. The OBS option is overridden by the NOOBS option. When the ILINK option is specified with binary response variables, then either the observed proportions or a coded value of the response is displayed. For polytomous response variables, the observed values are overlaid onto the fitted curves unless the LOCATION= option is specified. Whether observations are displayed by default or not depends upon the procedure. If the PLOTBY= option is specified, then the observations displayed on each plot are from the corresponding PLOTBY= level for classification effects; for continuous effects, all observations are displayed on every plot. The following options are available: BYAT -- subsets the observations by AT level and by the PLOTBY= level. CDISPLAY=NONE | OUTLINE | GRADIENT | OUTLINEGRADIENT controls the display of observations on contour plots. CGRADIENT=RESIDUAL | DEPENDENT specifies what the gradient-shading of the observed values on the CONTOUR plot-type represents. DEPTH=depth (you can specify 1 ≤ depth ≤ 100. By default, DEPTH=1) specifies the number of overlapping observations that can be distinguished by adjusting their transparency. DISTANCE displays observations on FIT plot-types with a color-gradient that indicates how far the observation is from the AT and PLOTBY= level. FITATCLASS -- computes fitted values only for class levels that are observed in the data set. FRINGE -- displays observations in a fringe (rug) plot at the bottom of the plot. JITTER<(FACTOR=factor SEED=seed X=x-jitter Y=y-jitter)> -- shifts (jitters) the observations. LABEL<=OBS> -- labels markers with their observation number.
arguments.help: OBS=BYAT | CDISPLAY= | CGRADIENT= | DEPTH= | DISTANCE | FITATCLASS | FRINGE | JITTER | FACTOR= | SEED= | X= | Y= | LABEL | LABEL= | LOCATION=

arguments.name: PLOTBY=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable or CLASS effect at whose levels the predicted values are computed and the plots are displayed. You can specify the response variable as the effect for polytomous response models. The panel-type argument specifies the method in which the plots are grouped for the display. The following panel-types are available. COLUMNS specifies that the columns within each panel correspond to different levels of the PLOTBY= effect and hence the rows correspond to different AT levels. PACK specifies that plots be displayed in the panels as they are produced with no control over the placement of the PLOTBY= and AT levels. PANELS | LEVELS specifies that each level of the PLOTBY= effect begin a new panel of plots and the AT levels define the plots within the panels. ROWS specifies that the rows within each panel correspond to different levels of the PLOTBY= effect and hence the columns correspond to different AT levels.

arguments.name: PLOTBYLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum length (1 ≤ n ≤ 256) of the levels of the PLOTBY= variables, which are displayed in footnotes and headers. By default, up to 256 characters of the CLASS levels are displayed.

arguments.name: POLYBAR
arguments.description: Displays polytomous response data as a stacked histogram with bar heights defined by the individual predicted value. Your response variable must be the SLICEBY= variable, and the INDIVIDUAL and ILINK options must be in effect; otherwise, the option is ignored. Confidence limits are ignored.

arguments.name: PREDLABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a label to be displayed on the Y axis. The default Y axis label is determined by your model. For the CONTOUR plot-type, this option changes the title to "label for Y."

arguments.name: SHOWCLEGEND
arguments.description: Displays the gradient-legend for the CONTOUR plot-type. This option has no effect when the OBS(CGRADIENT=RESIDUAL) option is also specified.

arguments.name: SLICEBY=
arguments.description: Displays the fitted values at the different levels of the specified variable or CLASS effect.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Preventing the INTERACTION plot-type from slicing by a second class covariate. Note that the SLICEBY=NONE option is not available for the SLICEFIT plot-type, since that is the same as the FIT plot-type.

arguments.name: effect
arguments.description: You can specify the response variable as the effect for polytomous response models. Use this option to modify SLICEFIT and INTERACTION plot-types. If you specify a continuous variable as the effect, then you can either specify a numeric-list of values at which to display that variable or, by default, five equally spaced values from the minimum variable value to its maximum are displayed.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Overlays a loess smooth on the FIT plot-type for models that have only one continuous predictor. This option is not available for binary or polytomous response models.

arguments.name: UNPACK
arguments.description: Suppresses paneling. By default, multiple plots can appear in some output panels. Specify UNPACK to display each plot separately.]

arguments.name: X=
arguments.description: Specifies values to display on the X axis. For BOX and INTERACTION plot-types, effect can be a CLASS effect in the MODEL statement. For FIT, SLICEFIT, and CONTOUR plot-types, effect can be any continuous variable in the model.

arguments.name: Y=
arguments.description: Specifies values to display on the Y axis for the CONTOUR plot-type. The Y= argument can be any continuous variable in the model.

arguments.name: YRANGE=
arguments.description: Displays the predicted values on the Y axis in the range [min,max]. By default, when the Y axis displays predicted probabilities, the entire Y axis, [0,1], is displayed. This option is useful if your predicted probabilities are all contained in some subset of this range. This option is not available with the CONTOUR plot-type.

arguments.name: CLIP
arguments.description: Has the same effect as specifying the minimum predicted value as min and the maximum predicted value as max.

arguments.name: (min,max)
arguments.description: Replace min and max with actual values.

statements.name: ESTIMATE
statements.description: The ESTIMATE statement provides a mechanism for obtaining custom hypothesis tests.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the final effect listed in the ESTIMATE statement from the 'Type III Tests of Fixed Effects' table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across estimates.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the estimates.

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: The default, which really signifies no adjustment for multiple comparisons.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed with confidence level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: BYCATEGORY
arguments.description: Requests that in models for nominal data (generalized logit models) estimates be reported separately for each category.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIVISOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of values by which to divide the coefficients so that fractional coefficients can be entered as integer numerators.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients be displayed.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Requests exponentiation of the estimate.

arguments.name: GROUP
arguments.description: Sets up random-effect contrasts between different groups when a GROUP= variable appears in the RANDOM statement.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that the estimate and its standard error are also reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LOWER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values less than the test statistic.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the CONTRAST statement.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN
arguments.description: Requests that multiplicity adjustments for the p-values of estimates be further adjusted in a step-down fashion.

arguments.name: SUBJECT
arguments.description: Sets up random-effect contrasts between different subjects when a SUBJECT= variable appears in the RANDOM statement.

arguments.name: UPPER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values greater than the test statistic.

statements.name: INSET
statements.description: The box or table of summary information produced on plots made with the PROBPLOT statement is called an inset. You can use the INSET statement to customize the information that is displayed in the inset box as well as to customize the appearance of the inset box.

arguments.name: CONFIDENCE
arguments.description: Confidence coefficient for all confidence intervals

arguments.name: DIST
arguments.description: Name of the distribution

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: Number of interval-censored observations

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Number of left-censored observations

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Number of observations with missing values

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Number of right-censored observations

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Value of the scale parameter

arguments.name: SHAPE
arguments.description: Value of the shape parameter

arguments.name: UNCENSORED
arguments.description: Number of uncensored observations

arguments.name: CFILL=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the filling box.

arguments.name: CFILLH=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the filling box header.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the frame.

arguments.name: CHEADER=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the text in the header.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the text in the inset. By default, the inset text color is the same as the other text in the box plot.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: Specifies the software font for the text.

arguments.name: HEADER=
arguments.description: Specifies the text for the header or box title. The string can be up to 40 characters.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of the inset and header text.

arguments.name: NOFRAME
arguments.description: Suppresses the frame drawn around the inset box.

arguments.name: POS=
arguments.description: Determines the position of the inset. The value can be a compass point (N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, NW) or a pair of coordinates (x, y) enclosed in parentheses. The coordinates can be specified in screen percentage units or axis data units. The default is screen percentage units.

arguments.name: REFPOINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference point for an inset that is positioned by a pair of coordinates with the POSITION= option. Use the REFPOINT= option with POSITION= coordinates.

arguments.name: BR
arguments.description: Bottom right

arguments.name: BL
arguments.description: Bottom left

arguments.name: TR
arguments.description: Top right

statements.name: LSMEANS
statements.description: The LSMEANS statement computes least squares means (LS-means) of fixed effects. As in the GLM and the MIXED procedures, LS-means are predicted population margins—that is, they estimate the marginal means over a balanced population. In a sense, LS-means are to unbalanced designs as class and subclass arithmetic means are to balanced designs.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across LS-mean differences.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the differences of LS-means.
arguments.help: ADJUST=BON | DUNNETT | NELSON | SCHEFFE | SIDAK | SIMULATE | SMM | TUKEY

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: DUNNETT
arguments.description: Dunnett adjustment (in which the procedure analyzes all differences with a control level)

arguments.name: NELSON
arguments.description: Nelson adjustment (in which ANOM differences are taken)

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. CVADJUST specifies that the quantile should be estimated by the control variate adjustment method of Hsu and Nelson (1998) instead of simply as the quantile of the simulated sample. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. REPORT specifies that a report on the simulation should be displayed, including a listing of the parameters, such as γ, ε, and α, as well as an analysis of various methods for estimating or approximating the quantile. SEED=number specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation.

arguments.name: SMM
arguments.description: SMM adjustment

arguments.name: TUKEY
arguments.description: If your data are unbalanced, PROC GLIMMIX uses the approximation described in Kramer (1956) and identifies the adjustment as "Tukey-Kramer" in the results.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means with confidence level (1-number)x100%. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default value is 0.05, corresponding to a 95% confidence interval.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Enables you to modify the values of the covariates used in computing LS-means.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that separate margins be computed for each level of the LSMEANS effect.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means. The confidence level is 0.95 by default; this can be changed with the ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of the LS-means be displayed.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all pairwise differences, and it is the default.

arguments.name: ANOM
arguments.description: Requests differences between each LS-mean and the average LS-mean, as in the analysis of means (Ott 1967).

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients for all LSMEANS effects be displayed.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that estimates and their standard errors in the "Least Squares Means" table also be reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LINES
arguments.description: Presents results of comparisons between all pairs of least squares means by listing the means in descending order and indicating nonsignificant subsets by line segments beside the corresponding LS-means.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients.

arguments.name: ODDS
arguments.description: Requests that in models with logit, cumulative logit, and generalized logit link function the odds of the levels of the fixed effects are reported.

arguments.name: ODDSRATIO
arguments.description: Requests that LS-mean differences (DIFF, ADJUST= options) and simple effect comparisons (SLICEDIFF option) are also reported in terms of odds ratios.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests that least squares means related graphics are produced via ODS Graphics, provided that the ODS GRAPHICS statement has been specified and the plot request does not conflict with other options in the LSMEANS statement.
arguments.help: PLOT=ALL | ANOMPLOT | CONTROLPLOT | DIFFPLOT | MEANPLOT | NONE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this LSMEANS statement be produced.

arguments.name: ANOMPLOT
arguments.description: Requests an analysis of means display in which least squares means are compared to an average least squares mean.

arguments.name: CONTROLPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display in which least squares means are visually compared against a reference level.

arguments.name: DIFFPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display of all pairwise least squares mean differences and their significance. Syntax: DIFFPLOT<(diffplot-options)> You can specify the following diffplot-options: ABS all line segments are shown on the same side of the reference line. NOABS separates comparisons according to the sign of the difference. CENTER marks the center point for each comparison. NOLINES suppresses the display of the line segments that represent the confidence bounds for the differences of the least squares means. The NOLINES option implies the CENTER option.

arguments.name: MEANPLOT
arguments.description: Requests displays of the least squares means. Syntax: MEANPLOT<(meanplot-options)> The following meanplot-options control the display of the least squares means: ASCENDING displays the least squares means in ascending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. CL displays upper and lower confidence limits for the least squares means. By default, 95% limits are drawn. CLBAND displays confidence limits as bands. This option implies the JOIN option. DESCENDING displays the least squares means in descending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. ILINK requests that means (and confidence limits) are displayed on the inverse linked scale. JOIN | CONNECT connects the least squares means with lines. This option is implied by the CLBAND option. SLICEBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to group the means in a single plot. PLOTBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to break interaction plots into separate displays.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the CONTRAST statement.

arguments.name: SLICE=
arguments.description: Specifies effects by which to partition interaction LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: SLICEDIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of simple effects be constructed and tested against zero.

arguments.name: SLICEDIFFTYPE=
arguments.description: Determines the type of simple effect differences produced with the SLICEDIFF= option.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all simple effects differences, and it is the default.

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN
arguments.description: Requests that multiple comparison adjustments for the p-values of LS-mean differences be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. You can specify the following step-down options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment should be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

statements.name: LSMESTIMATE
statements.description: The LSMESTIMATE statement provides a mechanism for obtaining custom hypothesis tests among the least squares means.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across estimates.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the estimates.

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. CVADJUST specifies that the quantile should be estimated by the control variate adjustment method of Hsu and Nelson (1998) instead of simply as the quantile of the simulated sample. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. REPORT specifies that a report on the simulation should be displayed, including a listing of the parameters, such as γ, ε, and α, as well as an analysis of various methods for estimating or approximating the quantile. SEED=number specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: The default, which really signifies no adjustment for multiple comparisons.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed with confidence level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Enables you to modify the values of the covariates used in computing LS-means.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that PROC GLIMMIX compute separate margins for each level of the LSMEANS effect.

arguments.name: CHISQ
arguments.description: Requests that chi-square tests be performed in addition to F tests, when you request an F test with the FTEST option.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the linear combination of the least squares means.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the linear combination of the least squares means.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIVISOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of values by which to divide the coefficients so that fractional coefficients can be entered as integer numerators.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients be displayed.

arguments.name: ELSM
arguments.description: Requests that the K matrix coefficients be displayed.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Requests exponentiation of the estimate.

arguments.name: FTEST
arguments.description: Produces an F test that jointly tests the rows of the LSMESTIMATE against zero.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that the estimate and its standard error are also reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LOWER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values less than the test statistic.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the CONTRAST statement.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN
arguments.description: Requests that multiplicity adjustments for the p-values of estimates be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. You can specify the following step-down-options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. The default is MAXTIME=60. ORDER=PVALUE ORDER=ROWS specifies the order in which the step-down tests are performed. ORDER=PVALUE is the default, with LS-mean estimates being declared significant only if all LS-mean estimates with smaller (unadjusted) p-values are significant. If you specify ORDER=ROWS, then significances are evaluated in the order in which they are specified. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

arguments.name: UPPER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values greater than the test statistic.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: MODEL response<*censor(list)>=effects </ options> ; <label:> MODEL (lower,upper)=effects </ options> ; <label:> MODEL events/trials=effects </ options> ; Only a single MODEL statement can be used with one invocation of the LIFEREG procedure.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Sets the significance level for the confidence intervals for regression parameters and estimated survival probabilities. The value must be between 0 and 1. By default, ALPHA=0.05.

arguments.name: CONVERGE=
arguments.description: Sets the convergence criterion. Convergence is declared when the maximum change in the parameter estimates between Newton-Raphson steps is less than the value specified.

arguments.name: CONVG=
arguments.description: Sets the relative Hessian convergence criterion; value must be between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: COORB
arguments.description: Produces the estimated correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Produces the estimated covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: DISTRIBUTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the distribution type assumed for the failure time.
arguments.help: DISTRIBUTION=EXPONENTIAL | GAMMA | LLOGISTIC | LNORMAL | LOGISTIC | NORMAL | WEIBULL

arguments.name: EXPONENTIAL
arguments.description: Exponential distribution

arguments.name: GAMMA
arguments.description: Gamma distribution

arguments.name: LLOGISTIC
arguments.description: Log-logistic distribution

arguments.name: LNORMAL
arguments.description: Lognormal distribution

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic distribution

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Normal distribution

arguments.name: WEIBULL
arguments.description: Weibull distribution

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Sets initial values for the regression parameters.

arguments.name: INTERCEPT=
arguments.description: Initializes the intercept term to value. By default, the intercept is initialized by an ordinary least squares estimate.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Displays the iteration history for computing maximum likelihood estimates, the final evaluation of the gradient, and the final evaluation of the negative of the second derivative matrix—that is, the negative of the Hessian.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Sets the maximum allowable number of iterations during the model estimation. By default, MAXITER=50.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Holds the intercept term fixed.

arguments.name: NOLOG
arguments.description: Requests that no log transformation of the response variable be performed.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Holds the scale parameter fixed.

arguments.name: NOSHAPE1
arguments.description: Holds the first shape parameter, SHAPE1, fixed. If no SHAPE1= value is specified, SHAPE1 is fixed at a value that depends on the DISTRIBUTION type.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to be used as an offset variable. This variable cannot be a CLASS variable, and it cannot be the response variable or one of the explanatory variables.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Initializes the scale parameter to value. If the Weibull distribution is specified, this scale parameter is the scale parameter of the type 1 extreme-value distribution, not the Weibull scale parameter. Note that, with a log transformation, the exponential model is the same as a Weibull model with the scale parameter fixed at the value 1.

arguments.name: SHAPE1=
arguments.description: Initializes the first shape parameter to value. If the specified distribution does not depend on this parameter, then this option has no effect.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Sets the tolerance for testing singularity of the information matrix and the crossproducts matrix for the initial least squares estimates. Roughly, the test requires that a pivot be at least this value times the original diagonal value. By default, SINGULAR=1E12.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set containing statistics calculated after fitting the model. At least one specification of the form keyword=name is required.

arguments.name: CDF=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the estimates of the cumulative distribution function evaluated at the observed response. If the data are interval censored, then the cumulative distribution function is evaluated at the response lower interval endpoint.

arguments.name: CENSORED=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to signal whether an observation is censored, and the type of censoring.

arguments.name: CONTROL=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable in the input data set to control the estimation of quantiles. If the specified variable has the value 1, estimates for all the values listed in the QUANTILE= list are computed for that observation in the input data set; otherwise, no estimates are computed. If no CONTROL= variable is specified, all quantiles are estimated for all observations. If the response variable in the MODEL statement is binomial, then this option has no effect.

arguments.name: CRESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the Cox-Snell residuals.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the new data set. By default, the procedure uses the DATAn convention to name the new data set.

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the quantile estimates.

arguments.name: QUANTILES=
arguments.description: Gives a list of values for which quantiles are calculated.

arguments.name: SRESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the standardized residuals.

arguments.name: STD_ERR=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the estimates of the standard errors of the estimated quantiles or x'b.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to contain the computed value of x'b, where x is the covariate vector and b is the vector of parameter estimates.

statements.name: PROBPLOT
statements.description: You can use the PROBPLOT statement to create a probability plot from lifetime data.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an Annotate data set that enables you to add features to the probability plot.

arguments.name: CAXIS=
arguments.description: Specifies the color used for the axes and tick marks. This option overrides any COLOR= specifications in an AXIS statement. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CCENSOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for filling the censor plot area. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CENBIN
arguments.description: Plots censored data as frequency counts (rounding for noninteger frequency) rather than as individual points.

arguments.name: CENCOLOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the censor symbol. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CENSYMBOL=
arguments.description: Specifies symbols for censored values. The symbol is one of the symbol names (plus, star, square, diamond, triangle, hash, paw, point, dot, and circle) or a letter (A–Z).

arguments.name: CFIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the fitted probability line and confidence curves. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for the area enclosed by the axes and frame. This area is not shaded by default.

arguments.name: CGRID=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for grid lines. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for lines requested by the HREF= option. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for tick mark values and axis labels. The default is the color specified for the CTEXT= option in the most recent GOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: CVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for lines requested by the VREF= option. The default is the first color in the device color list.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies a description, up to 40 characters, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu. The default is the variable name.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a software font for reference line and axis labels. You can also specify fonts for axis labels in an AXIS statement.

arguments.name: HCL
arguments.description: Computes and draws confidence limits for the predicted probabilities in the horizontal direction.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of text used outside framed areas. The default value is 3.846 (in percentage).

arguments.name: HLOWER=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower limit on the lifetime axis scale. The HLOWER= option specifies value as the lower lifetime axis tick mark. The tick mark interval and the upper axis limit are determined automatically.

arguments.name: HOFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the offset for the horizontal axis. The default value is 1.

arguments.name: HREF=
arguments.description: Requests reference lines perpendicular to the horizontal axis. If (INTERSECT) is specified, a second reference line perpendicular to the vertical axis is drawn that intersects the fit line at the same point as the horizontal axis reference line. If a horizontal axis reference line label is specified, the intersecting vertical axis reference line is labeled with the vertical axis value.

arguments.name: HREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the HREF= option.

arguments.name: HREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical position of labels for HREF= lines.

Alternating from bottom

arguments.name: HUPPER=
arguments.description: Specifies value as the upper lifetime axis tick mark. The tick mark interval and the lower axis limit are determined automatically.

arguments.name: INBORDER
arguments.description: Requests a border around probability plots.

arguments.name: INTERTILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the distance between tiles.

arguments.name: ITPRINTEM
arguments.description: Displays the iteration history for the Turnbull algorithm.

arguments.name: JITTER=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount to jitter overlaying plot symbols, in units of symbol width.

arguments.name: LFIT=
arguments.description: Specifies a line style for fitted curves and confidence limits. By default, fitted curves are drawn by connecting solid lines (linetype = 1), and confidence limits are drawn by connecting dashed lines (linetype = 3).

arguments.name: LGRID=
arguments.description: Specifies a line style for all grid lines; linetype is between 1 and 46. The default is 35.

arguments.name: LHREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for lines requested by the HREF= option. The default is 2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: LVREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type for lines requested by the VREF= option. The default is 2, which produces a dashed line.

arguments.name: MAXITEM=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations allowed for the Turnbull algorithm. Iteration history will be displayed in increments of n2 if requested with the ITPRINTEM option.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a name for the plot, up to eight characters, that appears in the PROC GREPLAY master menu. The default is ’LIFEREG’.

arguments.name: NOCENPLOT
arguments.description: Suppresses the plotting of censored data points.

arguments.name: NOCONF
arguments.description: Suppresses the default percentile confidence bands on the probability plot.

arguments.name: NODATA
arguments.description: Suppresses plotting of the estimated empirical probability plot.

arguments.name: NOFIT
arguments.description: Suppresses the fitted probability (percentile) line and confidence bands.

arguments.name: NOFRAME
arguments.description: Suppresses the frame around plotting areas.

arguments.name: NOGRID
arguments.description: Suppresses grid lines.

arguments.name: NOHLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses horizontal labels.

arguments.name: NOHTICK
arguments.description: Suppresses horizontal tick marks.

arguments.name: NOPOLISH
arguments.description: Suppresses setting small interval probabilities to zero in the Turnbull algorithm.

arguments.name: NOVLABEL
arguments.description: Suppresses vertical labels.

arguments.name: NOVTICK
arguments.description: Suppresses vertical tick marks.

arguments.name: NPINTERVALS=
arguments.description: Specifies one of the two kinds of confidence limits for the estimated cumulative probabilities requested by the PPOUT option to be displayed in the tabular output.

arguments.name: POINT
arguments.description: Pointwise (NPINTERVALS=POINT)

arguments.name: SIMUL
arguments.description: Simultaneous (NPINTERVALS=SIMUL)

arguments.name: PCTLIST=
arguments.description: Specifies the list of percentages for which to compute percentile estimates; value-list must be a list of values separated by blanks or commas. Each value in the list must be between 0 and 100.

arguments.name: PLOWER=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower limit on the probability axis scale. The PLOWER= option specifies value as the lower probability axis tick mark. The tick mark interval and the upper axis limit are determined automatically.

arguments.name: PPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the plotting position type.

arguments.name: EXPRANK
arguments.description: Expected ranks

arguments.name: MEDRANK
arguments.description: Median ranks

arguments.name: MEDRANK1
arguments.description: Median ranks (exact formula)

arguments.name: KM
arguments.description: Kaplan-Meier

arguments.name: MKM
arguments.description: Modified Kaplan-Meier (default)

arguments.name: PPOUT
arguments.description: Specifies that a table of the cumulative probabilities plotted on the probability plot be displayed.

arguments.name: PRINTPROBS
arguments.description: Displays intervals and associated probabilities for the Turnbull algorithm.

arguments.name: PROBLIST=
arguments.description: Specifies the list of initial values for the Turnbull algorithm

arguments.name: PUPPER=
arguments.description: Specifies the upper limit on the probability axis scale. The PUPPER= option specifies value as the upper probability axis tick mark. The tick mark interval and the lower axis limit are determined automatically.

arguments.name: ROTATE
arguments.description: Requests probability plots with probability scale on the horizontal axis.

arguments.name: SQUARE
arguments.description: Makes the layout of the probability plots square.

arguments.name: TOLLIKE=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion for convergence in the Turnbull algorithm.

arguments.name: TOLPROB=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion for setting the interval probability to zero in the Turnbull algorithm.

arguments.name: VAXISLABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a label for the vertical axis.

arguments.name: VREF=
arguments.description: Requests reference lines perpendicular to the vertical axis.

arguments.name: VREFLABELS=
arguments.description: Specifies labels for the lines requested by the VREF= option. The number of labels must equal the number of lines. Enclose each label in quotes. Labels can be up to 16 characters.

arguments.name: VREFLABPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the horizontal position of labels for VREF= lines.
